intro: Ibidium xyridifolium, commonly known as the marsh sedge, is a flowering plant native to wetland habitats in North America. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, which includes sedges and related grass-like plants. The plant has narrow, grass-like leaves and produces small, inconspicuous flowers in clusters. It typically grows in shallow water or moist soil, often in marshes or along the edges of ponds. Its botanical structure is adapted to thrive in aquatic or semi-aquatic environments, making it an important component of wetland ecosystems.
